learning_outcomes.description: Critically evaluate key economic concepts as they apply to policy making.
Communicate clear and persuasive arguments about the merits of an economic approach to particular policy contexts.
Leverage theoretical frameworks and case studies to evaluate current global economic issues.

assessments.weighting: <dd>32% Each quiz is worth 4% of your final grade. </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Quizzes (written in class, on paper) take place at the end of the seminar. Quizzes will consist of short answers to questions regarding the required readings for the same week (i.e. in Week 2 the quiz will ask questions regarding the readings set for Week 2). Since only the top 8 quizzes out of 10 count towards the final mark, allowing students to miss two classes without compromising their final grade, I will not provide alternative assessment unless under exceptional, and well-evidenced circumstances.

The quiz will consist of two question, each worth 2 points. The first will ask you to briefly define a key concept, based on one of the required readings. You will be assessed on the accuracy of your definition, based on the particular text. The second question will test your understanding of how the same concept is being used by the author(s) in the text. You will be assessed on how accurately you have used the concept, in line with its usage in the text. No half points will be given, so a score of 2 indicates a mostly or very accurate response to a question, 1 is partly accurate, and 0 is mostly or wholly inaccurate.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will hand in their quiz papers directly to Prof Hameiri

assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will write a 2,500 essay on a question supplied by the course coordinator.

The marking criteria will be available in Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.

In Week 13, students will complete a 90 minute in-class hand-written exam (plus 10 minutes planning time at the beginning). They will be asked to choose 4 out of 6 questions and answer in short essay form. Each question is worth 7 points for a total of 28.

Marking criteria for this assessment item will be available in Blackboard.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 2: Thinking like an economist

We will provide a basic understanding of the different schools of economic analysis and concepts used within each, explain some of the ways in which economic analysis influences policymaking, and consider some of the problems encountered in, or generated by, mainstream economic analysis.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 2: Thinking like an economist We will provide a basic understanding of the different schools of economic analysis and concepts used within each, explain some of the ways in which economic analysis influences policymaking, and consider some of the problems encountered in, or generated by, mainstream economic analysis.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 3: Markets and Market Failure

We will gain a basic understanding of the market mechanism, the different types of market capitalism, and how economists theorise and deal with market failure.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 3: Markets and Market Failure We will gain a basic understanding of the market mechanism, the different types of market capitalism, and how economists theorise and deal with market failure.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 4: The Economic Role of the State

We will gain a basic understanding of how economists view the nature and functions of the state in advanced economies and societies.
learning_activities.topic_title: Topic 4: The Economic Role of the State
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 4: The Economic Role of the State We will gain a basic understanding of how economists view the nature and functions of the state in advanced economies and societies.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 5: State Failure and State Capacity

We will further explain rational choice theory and its notion of ‘state failure’. We will also introduce the concept of 'state capacity' as alternative and discuss the debate between optimistic and pessimistic views of the ‘possibilities of politics’ for economic governance.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 5: State Failure and State Capacity We will further explain rational choice theory and its notion of ‘state failure’. We will also introduce the concept of 'state capacity' as alternative and discuss the debate between optimistic and pessimistic views of the ‘possibilities of politics’ for economic governance.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 6: The Economic Analysis of Institutions

We will develop an understanding of the main arguments and perspectives of institutional economic analysis and explore their views on the impact of institutions on economic policy and economies' performance.

Topic 7: Economics and Human Behaviour

We will understand mainstream economics' assumptions about human behaviour and how advances in behavioural economics have questioned these assumptions and developed different explanations for the interactions of human behaviour with institutions and the economy
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 7: Economics and Human Behaviour We will understand mainstream economics' assumptions about human behaviour and how advances in behavioural economics have questioned these assumptions and developed different explanations for the interactions of human behaviour with institutions and the economy

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 8: Taxation

We will understand the concepts and ideas that drive debates about unemployment and employment policy, and examine how competing economic perspectives influence policy debates and policy or have been ignored.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 8: Taxation We will understand the concepts and ideas that drive debates about unemployment and employment policy, and examine how competing economic perspectives influence policy debates and policy or have been ignored.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 9: Inflation and Unemployment

We will examine the nature of macroeconomic policy and its recent dynamics, investigating the interplay between fiscal and monetary policies and the growing challenge of coordinating them.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 9: Inflation and Unemployment We will examine the nature of macroeconomic policy and its recent dynamics, investigating the interplay between fiscal and monetary policies and the growing challenge of coordinating them.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 10: Banking and finance

We will discuss the fundamental principles of banking, consider the global financial crisis as a case study in systemic risk, and reflect on debates over the role of central banking and financial regulation.
learning_activities.topic_description: Topic 10: Banking and finance We will discuss the fundamental principles of banking, consider the global financial crisis as a case study in systemic risk, and reflect on debates over the role of central banking and financial regulation.

learning_activities.topic:
Topic 11: Economic Growth

We will examine the structural adjustment challenges confronting Australia and the concepts and ideas that drive debates about structural adjustment and industry policy, against the backdrop of the breakdown of economic globalisation.
